G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u202f19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000 and the property is located within Middlesex County.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u202f3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000 and the property is located within Middlesex County.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3).proposition: Venue in the Lowell District Court is proper pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3), as the property and cause of action arose in Lowell, Massachusetts.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from substantial interference by the landlord with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes and applies an “implied covenant of quiet enjoyment” in the tenants’ residential leases and holds that substantial interference by the landlord (through a commercial lounge the landlord controlled) breached that covenant and amounted to constructive eviction. The court focuses on substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment caused by conditions that were the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s actions or omissions, squarely aligning with the proposition that Massachusetts law implies such a protective covenant in residential leases.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: "He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge)." … "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from substantial interference by the landlord with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies, stating that "[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy." It further defines "quiet enjoyment" as freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises, and applies that principle to residential premises under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This directly aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts law implies such a covenant in every residential lease protecting tenants from substantial landlord interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Id. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” of any residential premises is liable for actual and consequential damages or for not less than three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: The presence of mold and unsanitary conditions also constitutes a breach of the warranty of habitability, established in Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and the corresponding health and safety standards in 105 C.M.R. 410.000, which set minimum standards of fitness for human habitation.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent discusses that the landlord’s obligations are measured by compliance with the State Sanitary Code and similar minimum standards, but it does not specifically mention mold or hold that mold and unsanitary conditions constitute a breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Moreover, as a separate opinion, it is not the controlling statement of the court’s holding. While Hemingway as a whole is foundational for the implied warranty of habitability tied to the Sanitary Code, this particular text does not clearly establish the specific mold-related proposition claimed.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt:
“Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code…fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units…

…by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: The presence of mold and unsanitary conditions also constitutes a breach of the warranty of habitability, established in Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and the corresponding health and safety standards in 105 C.M.R. 410.000, which set minimum standards of fitness for human habitation.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: While a breach of the warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment are distinct causes of action, the same acts—such as failure to remedy hazardous mold—may give rise to both claims.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats breach of warranty of habitability and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as separate, implied obligations and analyzes them in separate sections, confirming they are distinct causes of action. Although the specific facts here involve general disrepair rather than mold, the court’s discussion makes clear that the same underlying conditions (Sanitary Code–type defects in the unit) are relevant to both theories, even though the court ultimately finds no breach of either in this case. Thus, the case supports the proposition that they are distinct but may be based on the same acts.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. ... The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s conduct meets the threshold of “serious interference” recognized in Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), and Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case does not set or apply a specific ‘serious interference’ threshold; instead, it clarifies that liability under the quiet enjoyment statute requires at least negligent conduct—i.e., notice or reason to know and failure to act. The opinion cites Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority as an example of such negligent inaction, but does not itself find that the landlords’ conduct here met any ‘serious interference’ standard. Thus, it provides general fault and foreseeability principles, not direct support that a given defendant’s conduct meets the serious interference threshold recognized in Al‑Ziab and Doe.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Defendant’s conduct meets the threshold of “serious interference” recognized in Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), and Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: Doe explicitly characterizes the plaintiffs’ situation as a “serious interference” with quiet enjoyment when criminal activity in common areas prevents normal use of sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas. The court holds that such a serious interference can satisfy the quiet enjoyment standard if it is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, thereby providing direct authority for the level-of-interference threshold the proposition invokes.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f8A.proposition: By failing to maintain habitable premises and refusing necessary repairs, Defendant violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15B, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.750), as well as the implied covenant recognized by Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7\u202f14, 15B.proposition: By failing to maintain habitable premises and refusing necessary repairs, Defendant violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15B, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.750), as well as the implied covenant recognized by Massachusetts common law.

State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.602,.proposition: By failing to maintain habitable premises and refusing necessary repairs, Defendant violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15B, and the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.602, 410.750), as well as the implied covenant recognized by Massachusetts common law.

Richards v. Ready, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 271.raw_text: Richards v. Ready, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 271 (2007)
Richards v. Ready, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 271.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment was intentional, willful, and/or reckless, as Defendant was repeatedly notified of the problem and refused to take adequate corrective action.
Richards v. Ready, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 271.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the town and a neighbor created or maintained a nuisance through stormwater drainage and whether the town had a prescriptive easement. It does not analyze or discuss intentional, willful, or reckless interference with quiet enjoyment based on repeated notice and failure to correct a problem; instead, it focuses on the reasonableness standard for nuisance and the adequacy of the trial judge’s findings. There is no holding about a landlord-tenant style quiet enjoyment claim or the mental state required for such interference, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Richards v. Ready, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 271.relevant_excerpt: “Reasonableness is a question of fact for the [fact finder] whose decision is based on consideration of all the relevant circumstances including the amount of harm caused, the foreseeability of the harm which results, the purpose or motive with which the possessor acted, and all other relevant matter.” DeSanctis v. Lynn Water & Sewer Commn., 423 Mass. at 116. The fact finder must also balance the ‘utility of the possessor’s use of [the] land’ with ‘the harm which results from [the] alteration of the flow of surface waters.’ Ibid.

Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (20.raw_text: Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (2016)
Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (20.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment was intentional, willful, and/or reckless, as Defendant was repeatedly notified of the problem and refused to take adequate corrective action.
Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (20.case_name: Adams v. Congress Auto Insurance Agency, Inc.
Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (20.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns intentional, willful, or reckless interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment after notice and failure to correct, which is a landlord-tenant/quiet enjoyment standard. Guzzi v. Gage involves negligence and duty to safeguard personal information by an employer, including foreseeability and negligent retention, not intentional interference with quiet enjoyment or a landlord repeatedly refusing to correct a known problem. The case therefore does not address, much less support, the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Guzzi v. Gage, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (20.relevant_excerpt: “A plaintiff must prove four elements in order to prevail on a negligence claim: (1) duty; (2) breach of duty; (3) a causal connection between the breach of duty and damages; and (4) damages…. In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that the agency had a legal duty to Adams… to prevent its employee’s foreseeable misuse of the information that Adams provided to process his automobile insurance claim.”
